citations.desc: Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers.
citations.narrative:
Although the certifications of the last offerings of food and water, with a signature, for 20 dogs on flight CI512, AWB
29716472912, from PEK to TPE to LAX, were available, the specific instructions for the next feeding and watering for a
24-hour period were not. This information is required to complete the certifications. A system should be in place to ensure
food and water certifications, for dogs in transit, contain the required information.

Three of the 20 travel crates had food/water receptacles which were not securely attached to their primary enclosures.
Microchip numbers were verified by Animal Care personnel.
“Pipi” MC# 992001001497929, a female golden retriever. Her plastic water/food receptacle was not securely attached to
the travel enclosure.
“Maosi” MC# 992001001498349, a female golden retriever. Her plastic water/food receptacle was not securely attached
to the travel enclosure.
“Scarlet” MC #900219001330202, a female golden retriever. One side of her plastic water/ food receptacle was not
securely attached to the travel enclosure. This receptacle was also chewed on and the rim was torn off.
To protect the heath and well-being of the animas, food and water receptacles should be securely fastened to the the
inside of the travel crates and be constructed of such materials appropriate for the animals they are intended for. Food
and water receptacles must be securely attached inside the primary enclosure and placed so that the receptacles can be
filled from outside the enclosure without opening the door. A system should be in place to ensure the requirements are
followed.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.14(c)(3) 
   
Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers. 
Although the certifications of the last offerings of food and water, with a signature, for 20 dogs on flight CI512, AWB 
29716472912, from PEK to TPE to LAX, were available, the specific instructions for the next feeding and watering for a 
24-hour period were not. This information is required to complete the certifications. A system should be in place to ensure 
food and water certifications, for dogs in transit, contain the required information. 
3.17(c) 
   
Food and water requirements. 
Three of the 20 travel crates had food/water receptacles which were not securely attached to their primary enclosures. 
Microchip numbers were verified by Animal Care personnel. 
 
“Pipi” MC# 992001001497929, a female golden retriever. Her plastic water/food receptacle was not securely attached to 
the travel enclosure.  
“Maosi” MC# 992001001498349, a female golden retriever. Her plastic water/food receptacle was not securely attached 
to the travel enclosure.  
“Scarlet” MC #900219001330202, a female golden retriever. One side of her plastic water/ food receptacle was not 
securely attached to the travel enclosure. This receptacle was also chewed on and the rim was torn off. 
 
To protect the heath and well-being of the animas, food and water receptacles should be securely fastened to the the 
inside of the travel crates and be constructed of such materials appropriate for the animals they are intended for. Food 
and water receptacles must be securely attached inside the primary enclosure and placed so that the receptacles can be 
filled from outside the enclosure without opening the door. A system should be in place to ensure the requirements are 
followed. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.

n
